text: Portugal competed at the 2019 World Aquatics Championships in Gwangju, South Korea from 12 to 28 July. ==Artistic swimming== Portugal entered two artistic swimmers. ;Women {|class=wikitable style="font-size:90%" |- !rowspan="2"|Athlete !rowspan="2"|Event !colspan="2"|Preliminaries !colspan="2"|Final |-style="font-size:95%" !Points !Rank !Points !Rank |-align=center |align=left rowspan=2|Maria Gonçalves Cheila Vieira |align=left|Duet technical routine |76.2328 || 25 |colspan=2|Did not advance |-align=center |align=left|Duet free routine |75.6333 |31 |colspan=2|Did not advance |} ==Open water swimming== Portugal qualified two male and one female open water swimmers. ;Men {|class="wikitable" style="font- size:90%;" |- !Athlete !Event !Time !Rank |-align=center |align=left rowspan=2|Tiago Campos |align=left|Men's 5 km |53:57.2 |38 |-align=center |align=left|Men's 10 km |1:52:39.3 |49 |-align=center |align=left rowspan=2|Rafael Gil |align=left|Men's 5 km |53:45.7 |28 |-align=center |align=left|Men's 10 km |1:50:27.3 |42 |} ;Women {|class="wikitable" style="font-size:90%;" |- !Athlete !Event !Time !Rank |-align=center |align=left rowspan=3|Angélica André |align=left|Women's 5 km |58:11.8 |12 |-align=center |align=left|Women's 10 km |1:55:23.4 |19 |-align=center |align=left|Women's 25 km |colspan=2| |} ==Swimming== Portugal entered 10 swimmers. ;Men {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;
